TEI.2.document_title: William Rabb to Stephen F Austin, 11-24-1828

barker_notes.barker_summary: William Rabb to Austin, November 24, 1828. Has been compelled to abandon temporarily his settlement on the Colorado. Blames some of the settlers for the Indian troubles.
barker_notes.barker_citation: Eugene Barker, ed., Annual Report of the American Historical Association for the Year 1919: The Austin Papers, (Washington, D.C.: Government Printing Office, 1924), 3 vols., Vol 1, Part 2, pp. 144-145

*div1 type="summary"* *p*William Rabb to Austin, November 24, 1828. Has been compelled to abandon temporarily his settlement on the Colorado. Blames some of the settlers for the Indian troubles.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p**date_mentioned n="11-24-1828">Nov 24 1828*/date_mentioned**/p* *p*Dear Sir*/p*
*p*I have again been compelled to abandon my place *location_mentioned*above the La Bahia road*/location_mentioned*, much against my will I do assure You, So long as the *location_mentioned*upper Settlement*/location_mentioned* maintained their ground I did not dispair being able to complete my *location_mentioned*mills*/location_mentioned*; but after being deserted by my *person_mentioned*neighbors */person_mentioned*I deemed it useless, and perhaps unsafe, to remain there any longer;—however, I do not dispair of returning in a short time—nothing within my power shall be wanting to reestablish a *location_mentioned*Settlement */location_mentioned*at that place;—For this purpose I shall make such proposals to those who wish to Settle *location_mentioned*in that part of the colony */location_mentioned*as cannot fail being accepted by all who wish well to the country *location_mentioned*half my land at that place*/location_mentioned* will I give, if necessary, to effect this desirable object—could the *person_mentioned*uper settlers*/person_mentioned* view the importance of maintaining that place in the same light that I do, I am sure they would be less captious and hard to please than I am afraid will be found to be the case—If that *location_mentioned*settlement */location_mentioned*is suffered to break up and disperse it will be a misfortune to the *location_mentioned*colony */location_mentioned*that many years may not be able to retrieve— The late visits of the *person_mentioned*Comanchas */person_mentioned*must be ascribed to the misconduct and imprudence of some of the *person_mentioned*inhabitants */person_mentioned* themselves, who for the sake of a little base dishonest self interest would sink the *location_mentioned*colony */location_mentioned*in irretrieveable ruin—If some means could be devised to keep the *person_mentioned*Tonkuays */person_mentioned*and *person_mentioned*Lapans */person_mentioned*from coming among us, it is probable we should not be troubled with the *person_mentioned*Comanchas*/person_mentioned* unless they wish to commence unprovoked hostilities against us,— *person_mentioned*Two Indians of the Shawneys tribe*/person_mentioned* came to my place more than *date_mentioned n="10-xx-1828">a month ago*/date_mentioned*, stayed with me several days and then started *location_mentioned*up the river */location_mentioned*to explore the *location_mentioned*country of the San Sabo*/location_mentioned*—They have not returned at the time they appointed, which was last *date_mentioned n="11-19-1828">Wednesday*/date_mentioned*,*/p*
*p*Considering the punctuality of *person_mentioned*Indians */person_mentioned*in keeping such appointments I think it very probable that they have been killed by the *person_mentioned*Comanchas*/person_mentioned*, as they are now in the *location_mentioned*country */location_mentioned*through which they were to travel— These *person_mentioned*Shawneys */person_mentioned*had traveled a great deal through the *location_mentioned*U. S.*/location_mentioned* were *person_mentioned*men of considerable intelligence*/person_mentioned*, and must have had a good deal of influence with their *person_mentioned*nation*/person_mentioned*— They said that if they liked the *location_mentioned*upper country*/location_mentioned* their people would commence settling *location_mentioned*35 or 40 miles above the San Antonio road*/location_mentioned* within three months after their return—they left 58 deer skins, a little ammunition and some other *person_mentioned*Indian */person_mentioned*trinkets with me—I have brought them away and will leave them with*person_mentioned* Mr. Newman */person_mentioned**/p* *p**person_mentioned*William Rabb*/person_mentioned**/p*
*p**person_mentioned*Col. Stephen F Austin*/person_mentioned**/p*
